prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: XID 262 , 412 and 34 - continuum and CO emission -
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal contains observations of three targets. We aim at detecting the 2.1mm continuum (observed frame) for all of them as well as the following CO transitions: CO(6-5) in XID 262 CO(6-5) in XID 412 CO(5-4) in XID 34

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Estimate of required sensitivity for XID 262, 412 and 34
Continuum: By combining the UV to near-IR photometry from the CANDELS public catalog (Guo et al. 2013) with the far-IR photometry from Herschel public catalogs available in the CDFS (Magnelli et al. 2013; Wang et al. 2014) we built the broad band SED of the targets. For XID 34 we used the MUSYC catalog for the UV-to-near-IR coverage, since it falls outside the CANDELS area. By means of an SED decomposition technique that accounts for the contribution of direct stellar emission, as well as from dust-reprocessed emission from an AGN and from the stars themselves (Vignali et al. 2009; Pozzi et al. 2010; Georgantopoulos et al. 2013) we derived IR luminosities (L_IR), star formation rates (SFR) and stellar masses that are in good agreement with those quoted in the literature. Based on the best fit FIR SED we estimated a continuum flux density at 2.1mm (band 4) of 1.2, 0.7 and 0.3 mJy for XID 262, 412 and 34, respectively. We computed the exposure time necessary to detect the continuum emission of the faintest source with S/N>15 over an aggregated bandwidth of 7.2GHz. This resulted to be 30.2 min on target (x3 targets).
CO lines: With the adopted spectral setup we expect to detect the CO(6-5) transition for XID 262 and 412 and the CO(5-4) transition for XID 34. We used the L_CO(1-0) vs L_IR correlation derived by Daddi et al. (2010) for SMGs (see also Carilli & Walter 2013) to estimate L_CO(1-0) for the three targets. The CO(1-0) luminosities were then converted into the luminosities of the expected CO transitions using two different average CO SLEDs, one that is appropriate for SMGs and the other that is appropriate for distant QSOs (we note that our targets are indeed SMG/QSOs systems). The peak flux density of the CO lines were then estimated assuming a line width of 200 km/s, as measured for the CO(2-1), [NII] and [CII] lines in XID 403 (Coppin et al. 2010, Nagao et al. 2012, De Breuck et al. 2014). Under the conservative assumption that our targets follow the average CO SLED of SMGs (Carilli & Walter 2013), we expect a line peak flux density of 0.9, 1.2 and 1.8 mJy for XID 262, 412 and 34, respectively. With an exposure time on source of 30.2 min, as driven by our requirements on the continuum detection, the CO lines in XID 262, 412 and 34 are expected to be detected with an integrated S/N (over 200 km/s) of 5.3, 7 and 11, respectively (S/N=11, 15 and 18 assuming the QSO average CO SLED). This will allow us to have a good measure of the line intensity and derive the mass of the molecular gas assuming standard SLEDs (see e.g. Carilli & Walter 2013).

We will use 4 basebands in FDM with a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and a spectral resolution averaged to 16 km/s. This avoids exceeding the maximum allowed datarate and guarantees a good sampling of the line profile (e.g. over ~8-10 channels) for the brightest lines. The CO(6-5) transition of XID 262 and XID 412 will fall in baseband 1. The CO(5-4) transition of XID 34 will fall in baseband 2. The other basebands will be used for continuum observations.

We require a synthesized beam FWHM of 0.3 arcsec, that matches that of CANDELS WFC3 near-IR images. Based on our past work on XID 403, we verified that the angular size of the dust distribution is similar to that of the stellar distribution (Gilli et al. 2014). The three proposed targets appear as unresolved or barely resolved in the WFC3 H-band image. We therefore expect to detect most of the dust emission within the FWHM of the synthesized beam in band 4. The requested resolution (0.3 arcsec FWHM) corresponds to ~1 kpc half-light radius at z~3. The high S/N expected for our dust continuum observations (S/N=15-60) will allow us perform an analysis of the visibilities in the Fourier space as done in Gilli et al. (2014) for XID 403 and estimate an intrinsic source size below the nominal angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec if the source is unresolved. We note that the requested resolution is 5 times better than that of the existing ALMA observations of XID 34 (Hodge et al. 2013). The requested resolution is achievable with a standard array configuration (i.e. baselines < 2km).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: XID 403 , 546 and 490 - continuum and CO emission -
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal contains observations of four targets. We aim at detecting the 2.1mm continuum (observed frame) for all of them as well as the following CO transitions: CO(7-6) in XID 403 CO(5-4) in XID 546 CO(4-3) in XID 490

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Estimate of required sensitivity for XID 403, 546 and 490
Continuum: By combining the UV to near-IR photometry from the CANDELS public catalog (Guo et al. 2013) with the far-IR photometry from Herschel public catalogs available in the CDFS (Magnelli et al. 2013; Wang et al. 2014) we built the broad band SED of the targets. By means of an SED decomposition technique that accounts for the contribution of direct stellar emission, as well as from dust-reprocessed emission from an AGN and from the stars themselves (Vignali et al. 2009; Pozzi et al. 2010; Georgantopoulos et al. 2013) we derived IR luminosities (L_IR), star formation rates (SFR) and stellar masses that are in good agreement with those quoted in the literature. Based on the best fit FIR SED we estimated a continuum flux density at 2.1mm (band 4) of 0.6, 0.4 and 0.7 mJy for XID 403, 546 and 490, respectively. We computed the exposure time necessary to detect the continuum emission of the faintest source with S/N>20 over an aggregated bandwidth of 7.2GHz. This resulted to be 29.2 min on target (x3 targets).
CO lines: With the adopted spectral setup we expect to detect the CO(7-6), (5-4) and (4-3) transitions for XID 403, 546 and 490, respectively. We used the L_CO(1-0) vs L_IR correlation derived by Daddi et al. (2010) for SMGs (see also Carilli & Walter 2013) to estimate L_CO(1-0) for the three targets. The CO(1-0) luminosities were then converted into the luminosities of the expected CO transitions using two different average CO SLEDs, one that is appropriate for SMGs and the other that is appropriate for distant QSOs (we note that our targets are indeed SMG/QSOs systems). The peak flux density of the CO lines were then estimated assuming a line width of 200 km/s, as measured for the CO(2-1), [NII] and [CII] lines in XID 403 (Coppin et al. 2010, Nagao et al. 2012, De Breuck et al. 2014). Under the conservative assumption that our targets follow the average CO SLED of SMGs (Carilli & Walter 2013), we expect a line peak flux density of 1.1, 1.1 and 1.2 mJy for XID 403, 546 and 490, respectively. With an exposure time on source of 29.2 min, as driven by our requirements on the continuum detection, the CO transitions in XID 403, 546 and 490 are expected to be detected with an integrated S/N (over 200 km/s) of 6.3, 6.3 and 6.8, respectively (S/N=16.5, 10.8 and 12.5 assuming the QSO average CO SLED). This will allow us to have a good measure of the line intensity and derive the mass of the molecular gas assuming standard SLEDs (see e.g. Carilli & Walter 2013).

We will use 4 basebands in FDM with a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and a spectral resolution averaged to 16 km/s. This avoids exceeding the maximum allowed datarate and guarantees a good sampling of the line profile (e.g. over ~8-10 channels) for the brightest lines. The CO(7-6) transition of XID 403 will fall in baseband 1. The CO(5-4) transition of XID 546 will fall in baseband 2. The CO(4-3) transition of XID 490 will fall in baseband 4. The other baseband will be used for continuum observations.

We require a synthesized beam FWHM of 0.3 arcsec, that matches that of CANDELS WFC3 near-IR images. Based on our past work on XID 403, we verified that the angular size of the dust distribution is similar to that of the stellar distribution (Gilli et al. 2014). The three proposed targets appear as unresolved or barely resolved in the WFC3 H-band image. We therefore expect to detect most of the dust emission within the FWHM of the synthesized beam in band 4. The requested resolution (0.3 arcsec FWHM) corresponds to ~1 kpc half-light radius at z~3. The high S/N expected for our dust continuum observations (S/N=20-35) will allow us perform an analysis of the visibilities in the Fourier space as done in Gilli et al. (2014) for XID 403 and estimate an intrinsic source size below the nominal angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec if the source is unresolved. We note that the requested resolution is at least a factor of 2-2.6 better than that of the existing ALMA observations in XID 403 (Gilli et al. 2014, De Breuck et al. 2014). The requested resolution is achievable with an array configuration with baselines < 2km (i.e. in stardard mode).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose observations of the dust continuum and of one high-J CO transition in six heavily obscured QSOs residing in SMGs at z>2.5 in the CDFS. All QSOs are obscured by an X-ray column density of NH>3e23 cm-2. Their hosts are massive (M*>1e11 Msun) and feature vigorous star formation rates (SFR>300 Msun/yr).
Through band 4 observations with 0.3" FWHM resolution, i.e. half-light radius ~1 kpc at the median target redshift, we will measure the morphology and compactness of star formation and the mass and density of the ISM. With 5 hr of ALMA time (including overheads) we will assess whether: 1) star formation is taking place in a compact (~0.5-2 kpc) region, with size similar to that of compact quiescent galaxies (cQGs) at z<2. This, coupled to other physical quantities such as SFR, stellar mass, gas depletion time, would reveal whether our targets are the likely progenitors of cQGs; 2) the host gas density is so high that it can produce most of the nuclear absorption measured from the X-ray spectra. This might help explaining why the fraction of heavily obscured QSOs has been observed to increase with redshift.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
